items.title: Unavoidable warning if fsspec is not installed
items.body:
<!--
For bug reports, please follow the template below. For enhancement proposals, feel free
to use whatever template makes sense.
-->

#### Minimal, reproducible code sample, a copy-pastable example if possible

```
python -c "import petl"
# Missing fsspec package. Install with: pip install fsspec
```

#### Problem description

It is not possible to use petl without this warning, even if no remote I/O is used or intended.

#### Version and installation information

* Value of ``petl.__version__``: "1.6.0"
* Version of Python interpreter: 3.8.3
* Operating system (Linux/Windows/Mac): Windows
* How petl was installed: pip in venv

items.title: Deprecation warning due to invalid escape sequences
items.body:
#### Minimal, reproducible code sample, a copy-pastable example if possible

```
find . -iname '*.py' | grep -v example | xargs -P4 -I{} python3.8 -Wall -m py_compile {}
./petl/util/base.py:662: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \{
  prog = re.compile('\{([^}]+)\}')
```

#### Problem description

Deprecation warnings are raised due to invalid escape sequences. This can be fixed by using raw strings or escaping the literals. pyupgrade also helps in automatic conversion : https://github.com/asottile/pyupgrade/

#### Version and installation information

* Value of ``petl.__version__`` : master
* Version information for any third-party package dependencies that are relevant
* Version of Python interpreter : 3.8
* Operating system (Linux/Windows/Mac) Linux
* How petl was installed (e.g., "using pip into virtual environment", or "using conda")

Thanks!

items.title: Any idea to split a table into multiple tables or files based on row count or size?
items.body:
Hi There,

I would like to split a table container having csv data to multiple containers or to files based on row count or size.  It looks similar with petlx.push.partition, but use count or size instead of condition.
Is there any feature in petl or any recommended approach ?

Thanks!

items.title: Spark support
items.body:
I have just started look into petl and I wonder if the package support using Spark?
Because for big data, using pandas/numpy is impossible.

I have skim through the documentation and also the code, it seems there is nothing indicate that. So is there any plan in the future?

items.title: Support other dialects out of the box
items.body:
Currently pETL only supports built-in dialects:

DIALECTS = {
    'access': 'access.base',
    'firebird': 'firebird.kinterbasdb',
    'informix': 'informix.informixdb',
    'maxdb': 'maxdb.sapdb',
    'mssql': 'mssql.pyodbc',
    'mysql': 'mysql.mysqlconnector',
    'oracle': 'oracle.cx_oracle',
    'postgresql': 'postgresql.psycopg2',
    'sqlite': 'sqlite.pysqlite',
    'sybase': 'sybase.pyodbc'
}

Would it be possible to automatically support others?  For example, I am using CockroachDB with a dialect based on PostgreSQL which required me to hack db_create.py.

Thanks

items.title: Cannot pass 'encoding_override' to 'fromxls' for proper decoding
items.body:
#### Minimal, reproducible code sample, a copy-pastable example if possible

```python
>>> import petl
>>> a = petl.fromxls('/input/ba_una/receitas_20161201_20161231.xls', 0)
>>> a.head()
*** WARNING: on_demand is not supported for this Excel version.
*** Setting on_demand to False.
*** No CODEPAGE record, no encoding_override: will use 'ascii'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/petl/util/vis.py", line 135, in _table_repr
    return str(look(table))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/petl/util/vis.py", line 104, in __repr__
    table, overflow = _vis_overflow(self.table, self.limit)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/petl/util/vis.py", line 528, in _vis_overflow
    table = list(islice(table, 0, limit+2))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/petl/transform/basics.py", line 630, in iterrowslice
    yield tuple(next(it))  # fields
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/petl/io/xls.py", line 36, in __iter__
    wb = xlutils_view.View(self.filename)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/petl/io/xlutils_view.py", line 117, in __init__
    self.book = open_workbook(path, formatting_info=0, on_demand=True)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/xlrd/__init__.py", line 157, in open_workbook
    ragged_rows=ragged_rows,
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/xlrd/book.py", line 108, in open_workbook_xls
    bk.fake_globals_get_sheet()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/xlrd/book.py", line 732, in fake_globals_get_sheet
    self.get_sheets()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/xlrd/book.py", line 723, in get_sheets
    self.get_sheet(sheetno)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/xlrd/book.py", line 714, in get_sheet
    sh.read(self)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/xlrd/sheet.py", line 820, in read
    strg = unpack_string(data, 6, bk.encoding or bk.derive_encoding(), lenlen=2)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/xlrd/biffh.py", line 250, in unpack_string
    return unicode(data[pos:pos+nchars], encoding)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/xlrd/timemachine.py", line 31, in <lambda>
    unicode = lambda b, enc: b.decode(enc)
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xcd in position 5: ordinal not in range(128)
```

#### Problem description

I am dealing with an old excel XLS file and I cannot read it with `fromxls` because `xlrd` is assuming `ascii` but the encoding is actually “cp1252".

Could you please allow `fromxls` to receive an extra parameter `encoding_override` so we can instruct `petl` to pass it along to `xlrd.open_workbook` so the file can be properly decoded?

Thanks in advance,

#### Version and installation information

Python 3.7.3 (default, May 11 2019, 02:00:41)
[GCC 8.3.0] on linux

* Operating system: Mac
* How petl was installed: pip

```
petl/io/xlsx.py:53: DeprecationWarning: Call to deprecated function get_sheet_names (Use wb.sheetnames).
  ws = wb.get_sheet_by_name(wb.get_sheet_names()[0])
petl/io/xlsx.py:53: DeprecationWarning: Call to deprecated function get_sheet_by_name (Use wb[sheetname]).
```

items.title: Drop support for 2.6
items.body:
Since Python 2.6 is not supported by Python's core team anymore does it make sense to keep supporting it? Another nail in 2.6's coffin is the fact that currently the CI build for 2.6 is not even passing - dropping support for 2.6 is easier than fixing the build.

    DEPRECATION: Python 2.6 is no longer supported by the Python core team, please upgrade
                 your Python. A future version of pip will drop support for Python 2.6

People stuck with 2.6 can always install an older version of petl; it is 2018 and keeping support for 2.6 is not worth anymore.

items.title: optimized_write deprecation- openpyxl library
items.body:
Appears _optimized_write_ is deprecated in favor of _write_only_ for the openpyxl library.Workbook initialization. Here are my brief logs:

> [2018-04-08 20:50:39,067] {{base_task_runner.py:98}} INFO - Subtask:   File "/usr/local/airflow/dags/common/excel.py", line 33, in write_xlsx_from_result_set
> [2018-04-08 20:50:39,067] {{base_task_runner.py:98}} INFO - Subtask:     wb = xlsx.toxlsx(result_set, target_xlsx_filename)
> [2018-04-08 20:50:39,067] {{base_task_runner.py:98}} INFO - Subtask:   File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/petl/io/xlsx.py", line 79, in toxlsx
> [2018-04-08 20:50:39,067] {{base_task_runner.py:98}} INFO - Subtask:     wb = openpyxl.Workbook(optimized_write=True, encoding=encoding)
> [2018-04-08 20:50:39,067] {{base_task_runner.py:98}} INFO - Subtask: TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'optimized_write'

I imagine it'll affect anything under xlsx that uses the openpyxl library. Suggested fix is to use _write_only_ per version 2.4.0 (released 4/1/2016) [release notes](http://openpyxl.readthedocs.io/en/stable/changes.html?highlight=optimized_write#a1-2016-04-11).

items.title: fromxlsx only reads first 65536 rows
items.body:
Hi everyone,

I'm running into an issue where I have a file with about 100,000 rows, but xlsx.fromxlsx seems to stop reading at 65536, and no error is reported.

```
>>> import petl
>>> petl.__version__
'1.1.1'
>>> from petl.io import xlsx
>>> xlsx
<module 'petl.io.xlsx' from '/home/user/development/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/petl/io/xlsx.pyc'>
>>> dir(xlsx)
['Table', 'XLSXView', '__builtins__', '__doc__', '__file__', '__name__', '__package__', 'absolute_import', 'division', 'fromxlsx', 'locale', 'print_function', 'toxlsx']
>>> xlsx.fromxlsx
<function fromxlsx at 0x2b8b34d10050>
>>> x = xlsx.fromxlsx("/space/MyFile.xlsx")
>>> for r in x:
...     c = c + 1
... 
>>> c
65536
```

Is this a known limitation, or would this be cause by a dependency in my environment? I know that's the max row limit for xls files, but I do have an xlsx file which shouldn't have this limit.

items.title: Transpose for selected columns
items.body: Currently there is a way to transpose entire table, if we are in need of transposing specific columns there is no option for it

items.title: Tables created with different functions don't join properly
items.body:
It seems that tables created from different functions don't join properly. As a simple example: 
``import petl as etl

table = [['id','color'],[1,'blue'],[2,'red'],[3,'purple']]

table2 = etl.fromcsv('test2.csv')

table = etl.fromcolumns(zip(*table[1:]),header=table[0])

join_table = etl.join(table,table2,key="id")

print(join_table)

table = etl.fromcsv('test1.csv')

join_table = etl.join(table,table2,key="id")

print(join_table)``

For the first join, I use a table constructed with fromcolumns and the other with  fromcsv, and the join returns no output. For the second join, I use fromcsv to construct both tables, using the same data as previously. For this second join, however, the expected output is produced. I have attached the test csvs below.

[test.zip](https://github.com/alimanfoo/petl/files/1228734/test.zip)

items.title: Fix openpyxl.workbook unexpected arguments error
items.body: The call to openpyxl.workbook() in petl/io/xlsx.py throws an error as the arguments for calling this function have changed in the recents releases.

items.title: openpyxl >=2.4 throws use_iterators keyword argument unexpected
items.body:
Hi folks,

I am using petl 1.1.1 with openpyxl >=2.4. When executing 
```
rows = petl.io.xlsx.fromxlsx('excel.xlsx', sheet='Sheet1')
print(rows)
```

I receive 
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "[...]\test.py", line 9, in <module>
    print(rows)
  File "[...]\lib\site-packages\petl\util\vis.py", line 169, in _table_str
    return str(lookstr(table))
  File "[...]\lib\site-packages\petl\util\vis.py", line 104, in __repr__
    table, overflow = _vis_overflow(self.table, self.limit)
  File "[...]\lib\site-packages\petl\util\vis.py", line 528, in _vis_overflow
    table = list(islice(table, 0, limit+2))
  File "[...]\lib\site-packages\petl\io\xlsx.py", line 51, in __iter__
    use_iterators=True, **self.kwargs)
TypeError: load_workbook() got an unexpected keyword argument 'use_iterators'
```

A quick search via the gogler reveals, that the `use_iterators` keyword argument was removed as of 2.4 of openpyxl.

Workaround: use openpyxl <2.4 (e.g. 2.3.2)

items.title: distinct() filters None
items.body:
Is this the desired behavior? It's not mentioned in the docs, and differs from the way relational databases work (DISTINCT does not remove nulls). Specifying `key` and/or `presorted` produces the same result: ```python import petl as etl t = etl.wrap([['foo'], [None], [False], ['a'], ['a']]) t ```
foo
None
False
a
a
```python t.distinct() ```
foo
False
a

items.title: Add progress function that uses a logging handler
items.body: It would be nice to be able to direct the progress funciton (or a similar function) to a logging handler instead of a i/o stream.

items.title: Record object should support get() method
items.body: There should be a simple way to ask for a value from a field in a record and get a default value back if the field is not present. Python dictionaries offer the `get(key, default=None)` method which returns none if the key is not found or will return a default value if it is supplied and the key is not found. This would be very helpful for gettting optional fields and supplying default values when they are not presenet

items.title: Allow validation on optional fields
items.body:
I have some optional fields in my table. I also have some validation constraints that I would like to apply to them if they are defined. Currently, if a field is not defined but a constraint is applied, the following exception is produced:
`petl.errors.FieldSelectionError: selection is not a field or valid field index: 'digital_runtime'`

I would like to be able to apply validation to a field if it exists and ignore the validation constraint if it does not

items.title: appveyor CI
items.body: ...for running windows tests.

items.title: xlsx import uses old openpyxl call
items.body:
Using the latest available version of openpyxl from pip (2.4.0), this error occurs when trying to import an xlsx file in petl.

`TypeError: load_workbook() got an unexpected keyword argument 'use_iterators'`

`use_iterators` has been changed to `read_only` according to the current docs for openpyxl, therefore this issue can be fixed by a tiny change to petl/io/xlsx.py

items.title: Split cell into new rows, not just new columns.
items.body:
I propose a feature that would allow the use of regex to split a fields into new rows.  Currently, it's only possible to create new columns afaik, which causes a potential problem when the split yields different numbers of new data elements for every case.    Simple Example:

```
 [['ID','AMOUNT','RECIPIENT'],
    ['1','1000','Joe: 25%, Jane: 75%'],
    ['2','2000','Joe: 25%, Jess: 25%, Jenny: 25%, Jim: 25%']]
```

Desired Result:

```
 [['ID','AMOUNT','RECIPIENT','PERCENT],
    ['1','1000','Joe', 25%],
    ['1','1000','Jane',75%'],
    ['2','2000','Joe', '25%'],
    ['2','2000', 'Jess','25%']
    ['2','2000', 'Jenny','25%']
    ['2','2000', 'Jim','25%']
]
```

I'd be happy to give it a try if it doesn't already exist.  Looking for suggestion on how to implement, but I imagine it as some type of parameter you could pass to the split method.

```
>>> with open('ex.csv') as f:

...
"foo","bar"
"a",1.2
"b",2.3

>>>tbl = petl.fromcsv('ex.csv', quoting=csv.QUOTE_NONNUMERIC)

Traceback (most recent call last):

  File ".../petl/petl/util/vis.py", line 104, in __repr__
```

items.title: Boolean evaluation gotcha in SQLAlchemy
items.body:
Hey there!

When providing a `metadata` argument in the `to_db(...., create=True, metadata=None)` function with database creation, SQLAlchemy triggers an error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/etl/flows.py", line 178, in ETLFlows
    etl.todb(flows, pgconn, 'flows', metadata=table, create=True, dialect='postgresql', constraints=False)
  File "/env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/petl/io/db.py", line 335, in todb
    dialect=dialect, sample=sample)
  File "//env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/petl/io/db_create.py", line 225, in create_table
    metadata=metadata, dialect=dialect)
  File "/env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/petl/io/db_create.py", line 177, in make_create_table_statement
    metadata=metadata)
  File "/env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/petl/io/db_create.py", line 137, in make_sqlalchemy_table
    if not metadata:
  File "/env/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sqlalchemy/sql/elements.py", line 539, in __bool__
    raise TypeError("Boolean value of this clause is not defined")
TypeError: Boolean value of this clause is not defined
```

This is very likely to come from that [SQLAlchemy gotcha](http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/changelog/migration_06.html#an-important-expression-language-gotcha).

and there it is : https://github.com/alimanfoo/petl/blob/master/petl/io/db_create.py#L137

This fixed it for me : 
- Replace `if not metadata:` with `if metadata is not None:`.

I can create a PR later today, let me know if it helps. Not much time for that right now, just wanted to document this.
Hope it helps.

items.title: Python 3.5 compatibility
items.body:
Add Python 3.5 to tox test setup, check all tests run.

In particular, may need changes to accommodate https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0479/.

items.title: argument to `addrownumbers()` which allows user to set the target field name
items.body:
`addrownumbers()` adds a column which always has the name '`row`'. I consistently find that that is not the column name I want, so pretty much all of my usages of the function end up looking something like

```
my_table.addrownumbers().rename('row', 'id')
```

This leads to more complex-looking and less-readable code, especially since I have to invoke the string constant `'row'` the provenance of which is not immediately clear to the user (`.rename(0, 'id')` is also an option but still not as clear as I'd like). A clearer signature would be:

```
my_table.addrownumbers(field='id')
```

items.title: Utility functions fieldnames() and dicts() don't support unicode fieldnames
items.body:
Hello,
First of all thank you very much for petl. Very useful.

I am using petl to manipulate csv files from excel.
Loading is done with the fromcsv() function.
Columns have titles with non ASCII characters and file encoding is utf-8.
Loading is done flawlessly, but when I try to get the table as a list of dicts,
with the help petl.dicts() function, I get the well known error:

```
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in position 0-6: ordinal not in range(128)
```

I have narrowed down the problem to the base.asdicts and base.fieldnames functions which
use the str() function and not the unicode(), while iterating through the header fields.

I am using python 2.7.

Best regards,
Andreas

items.title: search / searchcomplement don't support non-ASCII characters

Both functions call itersearch() which applies text_type(v) on the value. We use Python 2.7 so that's equivalent to unicode(v). Is there a way to bypass the default "ASCII" encoding and use "UTF-8"?

Thanks! 
Chen

items.title: Joining to a table that has no non-key fields raises 'AssertionError: indices is empty'
items.body:
Urgency: LOW
Error Message: "AssertionError: indices is empty"
Code Snippet:
Suggestion: Joins between tables that contain only key columns should work.

``` python
# petl v1.0.11
import petl as etl

c = [['id','val'],[20,1],[3,1],[6,1],[12,1],[15,1]]
u = [['id','val'],[3,2],[6,2],[9,2],[12,2],[15,2]]
etl.join(c,u,key='id')

+----+-----+-----+
| id | val | val |
+====+=====+=====+
|  3 |   1 |   2 |
+----+-----+-----+
|  6 |   1 |   2 |
+----+-----+-----+
| 12 |   1 |   2 |
+----+-----+-----+
| 15 |   1 |   2 |
+----+-----+-----+

u = etl.cut(u,'id')
etl.join(c,u,key='id')

...

/tank/etl/anaconda3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/petl/util/base.py in
rowgetter(*indices)
    308
    309     # guard condition
--> 310     assert len(indices) > 0, 'indices is empty'
    311
    312     # if only one index, we cannot use itemgetter, because we
want a singleton

AssertionError: indices is empty
```

items.title: contents go missing when loading a generator using .fromdicts()
items.body:
input:

``` python
>>> petl.fromdicts(row for row in [{'foo':1,'bar':2},{'foo':3,'bar':4}]).tocsv()
```

expected output:

```
bar,foo
1,2
3,4
```

actual output (only the header survives!):

```
bar,foo
```

items.title: Why doesn't petl.todb method take a truncate parameter?
items.body:
I noticed todb method doesn't take a truncate parameter

``` python
def todb(table, dbo, tablename, schema=None, commit=True,
         create=False, drop=False, constraints=True, metadata=None,
         dialect=None, sample=1000):
```

But inside the method, it calls `_todb` method which supports a truncate parameter

``` python
        _todb(table, dbo, tablename, schema=schema, commit=commit,
              truncate=True)
```

Any reason that truncate is supported in `_todb` but not in `todb`?

items.title: Splitting a table into two based on a condition
items.body:
Add a function which splits a table based on a condition, returning two tables, one where the condition is True, the other where the condition is False.

This is convenience for two calls to select():

```
def biselect(tbl, *args):
    return select(tbl, *args), select(tbl, *args, complement=True)
```

Name of new function TBD.

items.title: Disable SQL quoting
items.body:
Add a global configuration option that would disable quoting of table and column names in SQL expressions. Also add keyword options to disable quoting for specific function calls.

Probably also add support for quote char to be changed globally and in specific function calls.

items.title: display table suffix
items.body: Add option to include text in paragraph following a table.

items.title: totsv() output of None value changed from empty string to "None"
items.body:
Not sure if this is a bug or an intentional change, but it was not certainly something I expected, or saw mentioned in the changelog.

In PETL 0.26 (Python 2.6 or 2.7):

```
petl.totsv([('fld',), (None,)], 'file.tsv')
```

produces a file containing:

```
fld
""
```

whereas in PETL 1.0 it produces:

```
fld
None
```

(PETL is awesome, btw!)

items.title: Set operation does not handle duplicate rows
items.body:
Forgive me if this is the intended result, but it appears as though the set operation (complement(), intersection(), et. al) does not take into consideration the occurrence of duplicate rows.

Using an updated example from the documentation:

```
>>> import petl as etl
>>> a = [['foo', 'bar', 'baz'],
...     ['A', 1, True],
...     ['C', 7, False],
...     ['B', 2, False],
...     ['C', 9, True],
...     ['C', 9, True]]
>>> b = [['x', 'y', 'z'],
...     ['B', 2, False],
...     ['A', 9, False],
...     ['B', 3, True],
...     ['C', 9, True]]
>>> aminusb = etl.complement(a, b)
>>> aminusb
+-----+-----+-------+
| foo | bar | baz   |
+=====+=====+=======+
| 'A' |   1 | True  |
+-----+-----+-------+
| 'C' |   7 | False |
+-----+-----+-------+
| 'C' |   9 | True  |
+-----+-----+-------+
```

I would have thought that both occurrences of `['C', 9, True]` should be excluded from the resulting table?

`petl.transform.dedup.duplicates` does not apply for my particular use case, otherwise I would just apply this before applying the set operation.

items.title: petl.fromdicts([OrderedDict(),...]) should use header ordering from ordered dicts
items.body: This would be nice to have and seems like a reasonable expectation for fromdicts() behavior.

items.title: .select() doesn't respect truthiness/falsiness
items.body:
The pythonic behavior for .select() would be for rows to be included in the output based on the truthiness of the function passed in. Currently however it seems to actually require the value to be False for a row to be filtered out.

For example:

```
In [1]: import petl

In [2]: petl.wrap([['heading'],['only this one is truthy'],[u''],[False],[''], [[]]]).select(lambda row: row['heading'])
Out[2]: # Only the the value that is actually False (not the falsey values) is filtered
+---------------------------+
| heading                   |
+===========================+
| 'only this one is truthy' |
+---------------------------+
| u''                       |
+---------------------------+
| ''                        |
+---------------------------+
| []                        |
+---------------------------+

expected:
+---------------------------+
| heading                   |
+===========================+
| 'only this one is truthy' |
+---------------------------+
```

items.title: addfield() behaviour on table with duplicate field names
items.body: Fields with duplicate names get dropped when addfield()?

items.title: Petl 1.0.6 - fromdb returning multiple rows from mysql table with only one row in it
items.body:
I've hit a problem where using fromdb returns 2 rows for a table in MySQL that only contains 1 row. I've included sample SQL below to create a demo table and code to show the issue.

SQL

create table petl_error(
    id int not null primary key,
    value varchar(20) not null
);

insert into petl_error (id, value) values(1, 'Hello World');

select \* from petl_error;

CODE
import MySQLdb
import petl

connection = MySQLdb.connect(host='localhost', db='test', user='user', passwd='password')

table = petl.fromdb(connection, 'SELECT id, value from petl_error;')

print "%d rows" % petl.nrows(table)

print petl.look(table)

OUTPUT
2 rows
+----+---------------+
| id | value         |
+====+===============+
| 1L | 'Hello World' |
+----+---------------+
| 1L | 'Hello World' |
+----+---------------+

items.title: Bug in db_create.py
items.body:
Hello,

I found bad command for oracle dialect in the file db_create.py
When I used the following command (db is SqlAlchemy engine):
etl.todb(table=table,dbo=db,tablename='TEST',create=True,drop=True,dialect='oracle')
this failed, because generated drop SQL script is not valid for Oracle database

in the file db_create.py is following line:
sql = u'DROP TABLE IF EXISTS %s;' % tablename

but Oracle doesn't support IF EXIST clause.

and there is another issue from Oracle point of view. In the file db_create.py is following line:

```
return text_type(sqlalchemy.schema.CreateTable(sql_table)
                 .compile(dialect=sql_dialect)).strip() + ';'
```

The issue is semicolon at the end of line , this semicolon caused that created SQL command failed in Oracle database.

Best regards

Paul

items.title: fromcolumns
items.body: Proposed to add a convenience function to wrap a list of columns as a table.

items.title: BZ2Source and ZipSource not usable on Python 2.6
items.body:
When reading CSV data, the source is being used as a context manager (opened with `with` statement). 
However the implementations of BZ2File and ZipFile in Python 2.6 do not support this, which raises an an AttributeError:

```
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/petl/io/csv_py2.py", line 42, in __iter__
    with self.source.open('rb') as buf:
AttributeError: 'bz2.BZ2File' object has no attribute '__exit__'
```

items.title: Whoosh example is not working...

Hi guys,

seems that the Petl - Whoosh adapter seems not to work, or I do not know where I do a mistake.

Tested on:
- Python 2.7.4  32-bit

```
import petl as etl
```

items.title: 1.0 change log and 1.0 source tag conflict re rowreduce
items.body:
The 1.0 release notes (http://petl.readthedocs.org/en/latest/changes.html?highlight=rowreduce) say that `rowreduce` is overly complicated and has been removed. The next paragraph of this document suggest using it in place of `recordreduce`.

It seems `rowreduce` is in the 1.0 source tree: https://github.com/alimanfoo/petl/blob/v1.0/petl/transform/reductions.py#L16

Perhaps the first use of `rowreduce` in the change log was supposed to be `recordreduce`?

items.title: petl.fluent diff() does not return fluent objects
items.body:
repro:

```
>>> import petl.fluent as petl
>>> dummy = petl.dummytable()
>>> dummy.look()
(as expected, prints a dummy table)
>>> added, removed = dummy.diff(dummy) # It doesn't matter that the tables are the same
>>> added.nrows()
AttributeError: 'ComplementView' object has no attribute 'nrows'
>>> added.look()
AttributeError: 'ComplementView' object has no attribute 'look'
```

expected:
'added' acts like an empty fluent table, meaning you can do `nrows()`, `look()`, etc. on it.

items.title: regexp itersearch expects ascii string and chokes on unicodes
items.body:
Hi,

I have a table staged in a sqlite with unicode strings. Running a petl.search or petl.searchcomplement with regexp on it throws the exception:
`File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\petl\transform\regex.py", line 342, in <lambda>
    test = lambda row: prog.search(str(row[index]))
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\xd8' in position 12: ordinal not in range(128)`

I solution could be replace the `str` with a `unicode` conversion in lines 342 and 347. I believe `unicode` is a superset of `str` and should convert any possible string correctly. As it is only required for `test` and not exposed externally the unicode conversion is permissable.

Cheers
Carsten

items.title: progress() raises zero division error when batchtime is zero
items.body:
When running progress() with a small batchsize specified can result in a batchtime equal to 0: 

For example:

``` python
d = dummytable(100000) 
p = progress(d, batchsize=100)
toscv(p, 'output.csv')
```

Yields:
batchrate = int(self.batchsize / batchtime)
 'ZeroDivisionError: float division by zero' error

I have a simple fix and I'll create a pull request.

items.title: petl.header delivers tuple or list depending on the table
items.body:
Dear all,

I have a table constructed from petl.fromtsv giving me table1=[('a','b','c'),(1,2,3),(4,5,6),...] and another table constructed by hand table2=[['a','b','c'],[1,2,3],[4,5,6],...] (in my unit tests). The first is a list of tuples, the second a list of lists.

petl.header(table1) == ('a','b','c')
petl.header(table2) == ['a','b','c']

assert petl.header(table1) == petl.header(table2)  # NO!

The documentation suggests that petl.header delivers a list and never a tuple. I can fix the issue for now by 
assert list(petl.header(table1)) == list(petl.header(table2))

But I would suggest to return either always a list or always a tuple independently from the underlying table data structure.

Cheers
Carsten

P.S.: petl rocks!

``` python
>>> import petl.fluent as etl

... .fromcsv('Defects_01Sep14.CSV')

... .cut('Issue ID')
... )

    raise FieldSelectionError(s)
petl.util.FieldSelectionError: selection is not a field or valid field index: Issue ID
```

Using the normal method works fine

``` python
>>> d = fromcsv('Defects_01Sep14.CSV')
>>> d = cut(d,'Defect ID','Issue ID')
>>> look(d)
+---------------+---------------+
| 'Defect ID'   | 'Issue ID'    |

| 'SW00001234'  | 'ISS04348205' |

| 'QM000338331' | 'CAS00751191' |
+---------------+---------------+
| 'QM001672364' | 'ISS04315142' |
+---------------+---------------+
| 'SW00286390'  | 'ISS04344781' |
+---------------+---------------+
| 'QM001645927' | 'ISS04324314' |
+---------------+---------------+
```

Note: fluent .cutout works as intended

items.title: Replace/Convert sets Mutable Objects to None
items.body:
Using PETL version 0.24.3.

Replace/Convert is setting anything that is a mutable object to None.  Consider this example:

```
>>> list_table = [['foo', 'bar'], ['a', ['b']], ['c', None]]
>>> look(list_table)
+-------+-------+
| 'foo' | 'bar' |
+=======+=======+
| 'a'   | ['b'] |
+-------+-------+
| 'c'   | None  |
+-------+-------+

>>> list_table = replace(list_table,'bar', None, [])
>>> look(list_table)
+-------+-------+
| 'foo' | 'bar' |
+=======+=======+
| 'a'   | None  |
+-------+-------+
| 'c'   | []    |
+-------+-------+
```

Immutable objects are not affected by this issue:

```
>>> list_table = [['foo', 'bar'], ['a', ('b',)], ['c', None]]
>>> list_table = replace(list_table,'bar', None, [])
>>> look(list_table)
+-------+--------+
| 'foo' | 'bar'  |
+=======+========+
| 'a'   | ('b',) |
+-------+--------+
| 'c'   | []     |
+-------+--------+
```

<!---
@huboard:{"order":280.0,"milestone_order":280,"custom_state":""}
-->

items.title: Change to include row in convert not backward compatible
items.body:
According to the info on the change to allow passing a row to a user-provided function on convert (https://github.com/alimanfoo/petl/issues/262), it appears the intent was to be backward compatible. However, it is not:

data.convertall(string.strip)

The above used to work without a problem, as strip's default behavior takes the first arg, strips, and returns. It accepts more than one arg, however, making the same code fail after the petl change. It seems that a more backward-compatible method would have been to introduce a new kwarg, like pass_row or include_row, as a flag so the coder can explicitly enable the behavior. Otherwise, we are left with the non-intuitive solution:

tr_strip = lambda x: string.strip(x)
data.convertall(tr_strip)

<!---
@huboard:{"order":281.0,"milestone_order":279,"custom_state":""}
-->

items.title: on Windows, sorts of large tables error out due to Permission Denied
items.body:
On Windows **only**, sorts of sufficiently large tables errors out due to `IOError: [Errno 13] Permission denied`

The error occurs when the number of rows in the table exceeds `petl.transform.defaultbuffersize` (default=100,000), and petl relies on temp files.

This is caused by a [known issue in Python and Windows](https://docs.python.org/2/library/tempfile.html#tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile), and thus is not readily solved by us.

A hack I've employed is to add the `delete=False` argument [when NamedTemporaryFile is instantiated](https://github.com/alimanfoo/petl/blob/master/src/petl/transform/sorts.py#L250).  However, the temporary file(s) will not be deleted automatically when the files are no longer needed.

I'm working on a way to handle this situation without changing defaultbuffersize.

<!---
@huboard:{"order":7.125}
-->

items.title: movefield() doesn't get wrapped in petl.interactive
refactor petl.io into submodules
refactor petl.transform into submodules
items.body: Refactor petl.transform into submodules, it's getting unwieldy.

items.title: preserve key field name in rangeaggregate()
items.body:
In the `rangeaggregate` function preserve the key field name in the output table.

Also applies to `rangecounts()`.

items.title: values() accept multiple fields as positonal arguments
items.body: It would be convenient to be able to pass multiple fields as positional arguments to the `values` function.

items.title: bool values are right-aligned in look
items.body: Should be left-aligned, only numbers right-aligned.

items.title: parsenumber as closure
items.body:
Proposed to change `parsenumber` to a function returning a function so the `strict` argument can be defined in the outer scope, and the inner function only takes one argument. 

This is required for compatibility with #262.

items.title: convert with row
items.body: It would be convenient to have a function which behaves like the existing `convert` function, but which provides the whole row to the user-provided function rather than (or in addition to) the field value.

items.title: dict get with default value
items.body: There's many places in the code where use of the get() method on the dict class with None as default would tidy things up.

items.title: runnable examples in docstrings
items.body:
Currently all examples in the docstrings are generating by running code by hand in the console then copy-pasting console output. However, each docstring doesn't have a completely runnable set of doctests, because some if the setup code has been omitted (e.g., definition of input tables).

Suggest making doctests completely self-contained and runnable then either using the doctest sphinx extension to verify output or use the autorun sphinx extension to generate output dynamically.

items.title: addfield with context
items.body: Similar to select with context (#257) I'd like to have a function which behaves like addfield but which provides the previous, current and next rows to the value function, so values can be created based on relationships between the current and adjacent rows.

items.title: select with context
items.body: I'd like to have a transform function which behaves similar to select() but which provides the previous, current and next rows to the query function, so filtering can be done based on relationships between the current and adjacent rows.

items.title: Showing Source of Conflict
items.body:
I'm using mergeduplicates to combine data from two spreadsheets and show the cells with discrepancies. I want the cells with discrepancies to show "Source1: value1,   Source2: value2" rather than the unordered Conflict((value2,value1)). 

When a conflict occurs, is there a way to determine the source of the conflict after I've done petl.cat on the data and performed petl.mergeduplicates?

One possibility might be to use petl.conflicts and add a column showing the source to each table? But, I prefer having the duplicates merged for readability purposes.

items.title: preserve key field name in aggregate
items.body:
In the `aggregate` function preserve the key field name in the output table. 

Also if a compound key is given, preserve as separate fields with the original name.
